all_summaries: This paper investigates the effectiveness of knowledge editing in correcting hallucinations by constructing a new benchmark called HalluEditBench, which includes a large-scale hallucination dataset derived from Wikidata. It evaluates knowledge editing techniques across five aspects: Efficacy, Generalization, Portability, Locality, and Robustness. Findings show that while some methods like FT-M perform well on prior datasets, their real-world efficacy is lower, highlighting the unreliability of previous evaluations. ICE and GRACE outperformed others in Efficacy, but all methods except ICE had limited improvements in Generalization. Locality scores indicated significant side effects on unrelated knowledge, with FT-M and ICE performing better. Robustness scores revealed that LLMs vary greatly in resisting external manipulations, with parameter-preserving methods like ICE and GRACE showing lower robustness. The study emphasizes the importance of evaluating knowledge editing techniques comprehensively to address real-world hallucination challenges.

Knowledge editing is evaluated on a new benchmark HalluEditBench, which includes 12,619, 13,210, and 14,366 hallucinations for Llama2-7B, Llama3-8B, and Mistral-v0.3-7B respectively, and the study reveals that while some techniques like FT-M show high efficacy on prior datasets, their performance on real-world hallucinations is limited, with ICE and GRACE outperforming parameter-modifying methods in efficacy, but all methods face challenges in generalization, portability, locality, and robustness, highlighting the need for improved knowledge editing techniques.
